instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Hello. I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not liquid damaged, and the board looks completely clean. When I connect the charger it goes to 20v .380a and just stays there. CPU and GPU voltage is not present but all the main rails seems to be fine. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.22v. I compared diode mode values on all the big coils with a good board and they seem fine. Here are some of the voltages I have measured.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  -  3.22
<SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  -  3.41
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>  -  3.31
<SIGNAL>LPC_PWRDWN_L</SIGNAL>  -  0
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>  -  0
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  -  0.976
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN_R</SIGNAL>  -  3.22
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  -  0
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  -  3.41
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>  -  3.32

L7030  -  12.66
L8000  -  1.012
L7960  -  0.964
L7900  -  1.2
L7600  -  5.14
L7660  -  3.3
L8410  -  0
L7410  -  0
L7420  -  0
L7211  -  0
L7221  -  0
L7231  -  0
L7330  -  1.053
LA640  -  0
LA650  -  0
LA350  -  0
LA300  -  0
LB700  -  0
L3500  -  0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Sorry forgot L8020.

L8000  -  1.012
L8020  -  1.8

I checked the voltages on all the outputs on page 74 and they are all present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Missing  <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  can be caused by bad PCH, or CPU.
However, try known good BIOS, as it is also involved there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: Yea I think its the PCH. I noticed after leaving the board connected to the charger for a few minutes, the PCH seems to get warm. The CPU does not feel warm at all. I have never replaced a chip of this size before. It it something that can be done using just the Quick 861DW or I will need some kind of rework station?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: A proper rework/reballing machine is required.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: Update on this one. I replaced the PCH on this board but I still have the same exact symptoms, so I don't think it was a PCH issue. The new PCH also gets warm though, as if there is a short to ground somewhere. I can't seem to find any shorts. Could a bad CPU cause the PCH to heat up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: PCH getting warm when the machine is turned on is normal.
